explanation:
For checking MISRA 'pointer should point to const when possible' we must know the exact types and function prototypes used so we can tell which pointer parameters are read-only and which are modified. Reasons: 
- OS_SockAddr_t: the Addr parameter type definition (and its fields) is required to determine whether Addr is used/modified by callees or treated read-only so it could be const.
- OS_common_record_t: sock_record and conn_record types (and name_entry member type) are needed to see if the code only reads from sock_record and whether name_entry is a mutable pointer or could be const.
- OS_stream_internal_record_t: sock and conn types (and stream_name, socket_domain, socket_type, stream_state fields) are required to see which members are written (so pointers to these cannot be const).
- OS_object_token_t: tokens are passed by address to several functions; need its type to know whether functions treat tokens as input-only or modify them (affects whether &sock_token/&conn_token could be const pointers in some calls).
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: macro/prototype that returns pointers into object tables — needed to know whether it returns const-qualified pointers or not (impacts whether sock/conn pointers could be const-qualified).
- OS_CHECK_POINTER: macro used to validate Addr and connsock_id; its implementation may take pointers by const-qualified type or perform writes/side-effects — required to determine const suitability.
- OS_ObjectIdGetById / OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew / OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew / OS_ObjectIdRelease: prototypes are needed to know which pointer parameters are outputs/inputs (e.g., token pointers, connsock_id finalization) and therefore whether those pointers can/should be const.
- OS_SocketAddrInit_Impl: prototype needed because it likely initializes/modifies Addr; if it writes Addr then Addr cannot be const.
- OS_SocketAccept_Impl: prototype needed because it receives &sock_token, &conn_token and Addr; must know which arguments it modifies to decide constness of those pointer parameters.
- OS_CreateSocketName: prototype needed to see whether Addr is only read (could be const) and what type/name entry parameter expects (const char * vs char *).
- osal_id_t and int32: base type definitions required to be sure pointer vs non-pointer usage (e.g., connsock_id is osal_id_t*, so we must know it's an output parameter type and whether it should be const).
- OS_SocketType (enum/OS_SocketType_STREAM): the socket_type constants clarify whether code only queries the field (read-only) or needs to modify it — informs const qualification of pointers to structures holding that field.
- OS_stream_internal_record_t::stream_name and OS_common_record_t::name_entry: explicit member types (char * vs const char *) are needed because the assignment conn_record->name_entry = conn->stream_name shows pointer-to-pointer usage; their const-qualification determines whether a const would be violated.

Providing these symbols (type definitions and function/macro prototypes) allows the next agent to determine precisely which pointer parameters and returned pointers are actually modified and therefore whether any could be made pointers to const under MISRA rules.
